data.question: What is the primary application of the 3D dynamic porous metal–organic framework mentioned?
data.answer: Selective gas adsorption of CO2 over N2 and H2.

data.question: What unique structural feature does the metal–organic framework (MOF) exhibit?
data.answer: It is assembled from fivefold interlocked closed nanotubes.

data.question: What method was used to obtain single crystals of the MOF?
data.answer: Diffusing an acetonitrile solution of [NiL](ClO4)2 into an aqueous solution of H3TCBA and triethylamine.

data.question: Why does the MOF exhibit selective adsorption for CO2 over N2 and H2?
data.answer: Due to the quadrupole moment of CO2, which induces interaction with the framework to open the channels.

data.question: What happens to the framework of the MOF upon heating to 50 1C?
data.answer: The framework of the MOF shrinks after the loss of guest water molecules.

What causes the large hysteretic behavior of CO2 sorption?
data.answer: The presence of the hydroxyl group and/or the secondary amines of L located at the surface of the pores, which can strongly interact with CO2 molecules.

data.question: Does the sorption capacity of CO2 decrease with increasing temperature?
